content:
Gratzer, Weinberger, and Buchholtz say in Directed univalence in simplicial homotopy type theory that synthetic quasi-coherence for distributive lattices holds internally in Dedekind cubical objects, which are presheaves on the Lawvere theory of distributive lattices.

Does a similar synthetic quasi-coherence for sets with two elements holds internally in Cartesian cubical objects, which are presheaves on the Lawvere theory of sets with two elements?

I guess turning the crank on Bleschmidt's general result (which applies to all algebraic theories and, in fact, to Horn theories), one concludes that inside this topos, if we have a finitely-presented I\mathbb{I}I algebra (where now an "algebra" is just an object with 0,1) then we get the duality-type isomorphism. Might be a bit boring though, since finitely-presented algebras are now I\mathbb{I}I with finitely many points adjoined and subject to a finite number of equations.

Is I\mathbb{I}I equipped with its hom-sets homI(i,j)≔∑f:I→I(f(0)=i)×(f(1)=j)\mathrm{hom}_\mathbb{I}(i, j) \coloneqq \sum_{f:\mathbb{I} \to \mathbb{I}} (f(0) = i) \times (f(1) = j)homI​(i,j):=∑f:I→I​(f(0)=i)×(f(1)=j) still a poset in this presheaf topos from synthetic quasi-coherence?

We have by synthetic quasi-coherence that the function type I→I\mathbb{I} \to \mathbb{I}I→I is equivalent to the free I\mathbb{I}I-algebra I[x]≃I+1\mathbb{I}[x] \simeq \mathbb{I} + 1I[x]≃I+1 on one generator, with equivalence eval:I[x]≃(I→I)\mathrm{eval}:\mathbb{I}[x] \simeq (\mathbb{I} \to \mathbb{I})eval:I[x]≃(I→I) such that eval(k)=λi.k\mathrm{eval}(k) = \lambda i.keval(k)=λi.k for the constants kkk in I⊆I[x]\mathbb{I} \subseteq \mathbb{I}[x]I⊆I[x] and eval(x)=λi.i\mathrm{eval}(x) = \lambda i.ieval(x)=λi.i for the generator xxx.

This implies that the only hom-sets that have elements are the reflexive hom-sets

(λi.k,reflI(k),reflI(k)):homI(k,k)(\lambda i.k, \mathrm{refl}_\mathbb{I}(k), \mathrm{refl}_\mathbb{I}(k)):\mathrm{hom}_\mathbb{I}(k, k)(λi.k,reflI​(k),reflI​(k)):homI​(k,k)

and the hom-set from 000 to 111

(idI,reflI(0),reflI(1)):homI(0,1)(\mathrm{id}_\mathbb{I}, \mathrm{refl}_\mathbb{I}(0), \mathrm{refl}_\mathbb{I}(1)):\mathrm{hom}_\mathbb{I}(0, 1)(idI​,reflI​(0),reflI​(1)):homI​(0,1)

and furthermore, by the equivalence (I→I)≃I+1(\mathbb{I} \to \mathbb{I}) \simeq \mathbb{I} + 1(I→I)≃I+1, these are the only such elements of the hom-sets.

From, this, one can show that, homI(i,j)\mathrm{hom}_\mathbb{I}(i, j)homI​(i,j) is a subsingleton for each iii and jjj in I\mathbb{I}I and reflexive, transitive, and antisymmetric, making I\mathbb{I}I into a poset. We can define the partial order as i≤j≔homI(i,j)i \leq j \coloneqq \mathrm{hom}_\mathbb{I}(i, j)i≤j:=homI​(i,j).

Now, defining the 2-simplex Δ2≔∑i,j:IhomI(i,j)\Delta^2 \coloneqq \sum_{i, j:\mathbb{I}} \mathrm{hom}_\mathbb{I}(i, j)Δ2:=∑i,j:I​homI​(i,j) as the fibred hom-set of the interval, do we have Δ2≃I→I\Delta^2 \simeq \mathbb{I} \to \mathbb{I}Δ2≃I→I? Yes, because both are equivalent to I[x]≃I+1\mathbb{I}[x] \simeq \mathbb{I} + 1I[x]≃I+1. For Δ2\Delta^2Δ2, we have for all kkk in I⊆I[x]\mathbb{I} \subseteq \mathbb{I}[x]I⊆I[x] the elements

(k,k,λi.k,reflI(k),reflI(k)):Δ2(k, k, \lambda i.k, \mathrm{refl}_\mathbb{I}(k), \mathrm{refl}_\mathbb{I}(k)):\Delta^2(k,k,λi.k,reflI​(k),reflI​(k)):Δ2

and for the generator xxx in 1⊆I[x]1 \subseteq \mathbb{I}[x]1⊆I[x] we have

(0,1,λi.i,reflI(0),reflI(1)):Δ2(0, 1, \lambda i.i, \mathrm{refl}_\mathbb{I}(0), \mathrm{refl}_\mathbb{I}(1)):\Delta^2(0,1,λi.i,reflI​(0),reflI​(1)):Δ2

As a result, by synthetic quasi-coherence, we have, for all functions f:I→If:\mathbb{I} \to \mathbb{I}f:I→I, an element

(f(0),f(1),f,reflI(f(0)),reflI(f(1))):Δ2(f(0), f(1), f, \mathrm{refl}_\mathbb{I}(f(0)), \mathrm{refl}_\mathbb{I}(f(1))):\Delta^2(f(0),f(1),f,reflI​(f(0)),reflI​(f(1))):Δ2

The quasi-inverse function is given by the third projection function of Δ2\Delta^2Δ2 as a record type, and since both Δ2\Delta^2Δ2 and I[x]\mathbb{I}[x]I[x] are sets, quasi-invertibility is sufficient to establish this as an equivalence. Since homI(i,j)\mathrm{hom}_\mathbb{I}(i, j)homI​(i,j) is a subsingleton for all iii and jjj, evaluation of functions at 000 and 111, (I→I)→(I×I)(\mathbb{I} \to \mathbb{I}) \to (\mathbb{I} \times \mathbb{I})(I→I)→(I×I) is an embedding, given by composing the equivalence (I→I)≃Δ2(\mathbb{I} \to \mathbb{I}) \simeq \Delta^2(I→I)≃Δ2 with the projection function Δ2→(I×I)\Delta^2 \to (\mathbb{I} \times \mathbb{I})Δ2→(I×I).

We also have that Δ2\Delta^2Δ2 is equivalent to the set of monotonic functions from the booleans 2→I\mathbb{2} \to \mathbb{I}2→I by recursion on the booleans.

Δ2≃∑f:2→IhomI(f(0),f(1))\Delta^2 \simeq \sum_{f:\mathbb{2} \to \mathbb{I}} \mathrm{hom}_\mathbb{I}(f(0), f(1))Δ2≃∑f:2→I​homI​(f(0),f(1))
By induction on the natural numbers one can show that nnn-ary operations on I\mathbb{I}I are equivalent to monotonic nnn-ary functions from the booleans to I\mathbb{I}I.

I just realised why higher category theorists use the set Δ2≔∑i,j:Ij≤i\Delta^2 \coloneqq \sum_{i, j:\mathbb{I}} j \leq iΔ2:=∑i,j:I​j≤i instead of the set Δ2≔∑i,j:Ii≤j\Delta_2 \coloneqq \sum_{i, j:\mathbb{I}} i \leq jΔ2​:=∑i,j:I​i≤j, it's because composition of morphisms is defined as g∘f=hg \circ f = hg∘f=h instead of f∘g=hf \circ g = hf∘g=h, for objects x,y,z:Ax, y, z:Ax,y,z:A and morphisms f:homA(x,y)f:\mathrm{hom}_A(x, y)f:homA​(x,y), g:homA(y,z)g:\mathrm{hom}_A(y, z)g:homA​(y,z), h:homA(x,z)h:\mathrm{hom}_A(x, z)h:homA​(x,z).

I don't think it's possible to prove that 0:I0:\mathbb{I}0:I is an initial object and 1:I1:\mathbb{I}1:I is a terminal object with only synthetic quasi-coherence.

But if we add axioms 7 and 8 from the paper mentioned in the original post, I\mathbb{I}I is "bounded" in the sense that for all i:Ii:\mathbb{I}i:I, the functions λj.λz.j:I→(homI(0,i)→I)\lambda j.\lambda z.j:\mathbb{I} \to (\mathrm{hom}_\mathbb{I}(0, i) \to \mathbb{I})λj.λz.j:I→(homI​(0,i)→I) and λj.λz.j:I→(homI(i,1)→I)\lambda j.\lambda z.j:\mathbb{I} \to (\mathrm{hom}_\mathbb{I}(i, 1) \to \mathbb{I})λj.λz.j:I→(homI​(i,1)→I) are equivalences. This is because for all f:In→If:\mathbb{I}^n \to \mathbb{I}f:In→I and v:2n⊆Inv:2^n \subseteq \mathbb{I}^nv:2n⊆In, homI(0,f(v))\mathrm{hom}_\mathbb{I}(0, f(v))homI​(0,f(v)) and homI(f(v),1)\mathrm{hom}_\mathbb{I}(f(v), 1)homI​(f(v),1). This allows us to treat 000 and 111 as if they were the initial and terminal objects of I\mathbb{I}I respectively.
